moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4: after 1. d4 d5 I chose Queen's gambit to play.
moves.2... e6: Black defends his pawn. I see this option almost every time I play Queen's gambit.
moves.3. Nc3: So, I continued with Nc3, intending Bf4 and Nb5 later on, which I have never tried to play.
moves.3... Be7: Black continues by developing his Bishop on e7.
moves.4. Bf4: I played as I wanted, but later on someting changed...
moves.4... Nf6: Black puts his knight on f6, which allowed me to play 5. Nb5, but...
moves.5. e3: I thought it would be better if first I give some places to my bishop to go and also to defend my c4 pawn.
moves.5... a6: With this Black avoided my next intended, Nb5 move.
moves.6. Nf3: I had nothing to do, but to develop my other minor pieces and to keep on planning.
moves.6... b6: I think this was the first wrong move from Black. Guess if what was my next move!
moves.7. Ne5:
Of course I centralized my knight! He would have some options. 1:Try to chase my knight away with some moves which takes too long. (for example: Nfd7, and after f6 or Bf6) 2:Try to exchange knights, with the same Nfd7 move
But two things were sure. 1:He has no Nc6 move 2: ...
moves.7... Nbd7: He has no Nbd7 move, because of:
moves.8. Nc6: His Queen is trapped. Resignation from Black followed. I hope you enjoyed this annotation, feel free to comment! Thank you for your the attention!
